twitter.text:
Telling a newbie what @billions_ntwk is about! 

Billion Network is about fixing the fact that the internet doesn‚Äôt know who or what it‚Äôs talking to anymore.

Right now:
Bots pretend to be people
People run many fake accounts
AI talks like humans without saying it‚Äôs AI
Trust online is basically broken

Billion Network is trying to solve that one problem.

Their idea is simple at the core:
Every human should be able to prove they‚Äôre a real human
Every AI should be clearly known as AI
You shouldn‚Äôt have to give up your personal info to do that

So instead of:
‚ÄúTrust me bro‚Äù
Or uploading your ID everywhere
Or bots flooding systems

You get:
A one-time proof that you‚Äôre real
A way to show that proof anywhere that supports it
Clear separation between humans and machines

They‚Äôre not trying to be a social app.
They‚Äôre not trying to be another Twitter.
They‚Äôre trying to be the layer underneath like plumbing that other apps use so they can stop guessing who‚Äôs real.

If it works, it means:
Less b0t spam
Fairer online systems (votes, rewards, access)
AI that‚Äôs transparent instead of pretending

That‚Äôs it.
No hype talk.
No buzzwords.

Just an attempt to restore trust on the internet in a world full of bots and AI

The Vision & Roadmap of @billions_ntwk
Their goal is to build a "Global Trust Economy" through three distinct phases:
- Human & AI Internet: Establishing the foundational boundary between humans and machines.
-Reputation Layer: Moving beyond "proof of personhood" to "proof of

It‚Äôs not a penalty, not a downgrade, and nothing negative.

What matters is rewards. @billions_ntwk rewards will be calculated using both leaderboards together.

So if your spot changed, nothing‚Äôs wrong ‚Äî only the category shifted, not your value or your rewards.

We've talked about the Know Your Agent (KYA) tech stack that @billions_ntwk is building, but how does it work?

The KYA tech stack is supposed to give AI agents some kind of identity and/or reputation that helps users kind of build trust in them.

‚Ä¢ First, those AI agents get identities, which is done using Agent JS SDK to generate each agent's unique Decentralized Identifiers or DID, which allows the agent to verify itself to humans and other agents.

‚Ä¢ After an Agent gets a DID, humans, organizations, and other agents can start making public attestations about it.
Attestations are permissionless, onchain, and linked to the agent cryptographically. They help potential users get knowledge about the agent to help build trust. Some of the information that can be linked includes:
          ‚Ä£ The agent's authentication
          ‚Ä£ Who owns it (developer or organization)
          ‚Ä£ Who trained it or built it
          ‚Ä£ Who audited it and the results
          ‚Ä£ Reputation signals
These attestations are stored in the Public Attestation Registry on the Billions chain.

‚Ä¢ KYA uses a hybrid trust model by design, which allows the preservation of humans' privacy while still keeping the agent accountable

‚Ä¢ Finally, the reputation of the agent builds over time because of its DID, which is linked to the agent's ownership. So whenever the agent is audited, reputation signals are added, or other agents build or reference an already trusted agent (like when an AI platform uses ChatGPT as its provider), the reputation of the agent grows making it more trustworthy.

That example genuinely made me pause.
Not crossing a border.
Not unlocking a phone.
Just signing a shareholder proxy ‚Äî and being asked for fingerprints.

This is what happens when ‚Äúverify everything‚Äù quietly turns into
‚Äúcollect everything.‚Äù
At that point, it stops being about security and starts looking like surveillance.

That‚Äôs why what @billions_ntwk is building with ZK-based verification really matters.
Proving identity, accreditation, or uniqueness without exposing raw personal data should be the baseline, not the exception.
The fact that institutions like HSBC, Sony Bank, and Deutsche Bank already use this isn‚Äôt theory ‚Äî it‚Äôs reality.

I‚Äôm with @lex_node on this one.
The tech is ready.
Now lawyers and platforms need to catch up ‚Äî fast.

.@billions_ntwk is more than a Web3 social media platform.
It‚Äôs a movement.
Just like the crowd.
Every individual carries the vision.
Connecting, sharing, and building together.
 In a decentralized world.
One symbol, billions of voices.

Quietly earning trust across ecosystems is how real networks are built.

Proof of humanity without exposing identity
@billions_ntwk @jgonzalezferrer @provenauthority @Mugi_wara_95 @maisha_anj63027 @lizzyy1268 https://t.co/DfJdhvdGKT

AI Agents Are Already Making Decisions. But Who Is Responsible?

Everyone is busy building AI agents.
Very few are asking who owns them, who controls them, and who is responsible when something goes wrong.

That gap is already showing.
An AI agent can trade, approve, message users, move funds.

But today, most of them have no real identity.
No ownership clarity.
No accountability trail.

That is not a future problem. That is a now problem.

This is why Know Your Agent from @billions_ntwk matters to me.
Not because it sounds fancy.
But because it fixes the boring, uncomfortable layer everyone avoids.

Instead of asking users to blindly trust agents, it flips the model: Agents get identities.
Trust becomes verifiable.
Reputation becomes public and earned over time.

What stood out most is the separation they keep very clear: Humans stay private using zero knowledge.
Agents stay accountable using public attestations.
No surveillance theatre.
No black box trust.
Just clear responsibility.

As AI agents move from tools to economic actors, this kind of infrastructure stops being optional.
Enterprises will demand it.
Builders will need it.
Users will expect it.

The AI future will not break because models are bad.
It will break if accountability is missing.
Know Your Agent feels like one of those quiet primitives that everything else will eventually depend on.

my journey with @billions_ntwk and what made me lock in

what web3 lost in recent years is trust. people don‚Äôt invest in crypto because they‚Äôve been burned or projects vanish overnight. i‚Äôve seen it myself, funds stuck, promises broken, hype over substance.
i always give examples from the telegram airdrop era: i lost up to $150 in a single trade, and over $700 in 2025 alone. that made me feel like giving up. what kept me going was hope that human protocols could solve this trust issue‚Ä¶ but in the end, nothing changed. what really made me sad was at TGE, they didn‚Äôt even recognize their own community ,they marked us as bots, even after i spent time getting my palm scan verified.
so i joined @billions_ntwk in march. after reading the project, i felt confident from day one. if you check my facebook, you‚Äôll see. alhamdulillah, now billions network is proving they won‚Äôt fail me, especially when i hear sony bank is starting to use them. i‚Äôm honestly happier than i can even explain.
@billions_ntwk stands out üíØ. they bring real accountability and verifiable trust. what‚Äôs next? honestly, i believe in billions, no be hype. it feels different, and i‚Äôm excited to be early.
